extendedIngredients.name: corn tortillas
extendedIngredients.original: 12 5- to 6-inch-diam corn tortillas or 8 7- to 8-inch-diam flour tortillas
extendedIngredients.originalName: 5- to 6-inch-diam corn tortillas or 8 7- to 8-inch-diam flour tortillas

extendedIngredients.originalName: smoked tuna (albacore), or smoked trout fillets, coarsely flaked

title: Smoked Salmon Flautas
summary: Smoked Salmon Flautas is a gluten free, dairy free, and pescatarian recipe with 8 servings. One portion of this dish contains about 24g of protein, 14g of fat, and a total of 753 calories. For $1.99 per serving, this recipe covers 29% of your daily requirements of vitamins and minerals. Only a few people made this recipe, and 1 would say it hit the spot. If you have parsley, basil, cilantro, and a few other ingredients on hand, you can make it. To use up the olive oil you could follow this main course with the Sauteed Banana, Granolan and Yogurt Parfait as a dessert. It works well as a rather cheap main course. From preparation to the plate, this recipe takes roughly 45 minutes. All things considered, we decided this recipe deserves a spoonacular score of 91%. This score is excellent. Try Taquitos o Flautas de Pollo (Chicken Taquitos or Flautas), Salmon With Beurre Rouge And Smoked-salmon-stuffed Baked Potato, and Rollo De Salmon Ahumado Con Salsa Tartar Y Lentejas (Smoked Salmon Roll with Tartar Sauce and Lentils) for similar recipes.

winePairing.pairingText: Pinot Grigio, Gruener Veltliner, and Pinot Noir are my top picks for Fish. Fish is as diverse as wine, so it's hard to pick wines that go with every fish. A crisp white wine, such as a pinot grigio or Gr√ºner Veltliner, will suit any delicately flavored white fish. Meaty, strongly flavored fish such as salmon and tuna can even handle a light red wine, such as a pinot noir. You could try Mark West Pinot Grigio. Reviewers quite like it with a 4.5 out of 5 star rating and a price of about 13 dollars per bottle.

productMatches.title: Mark West Pinot Grigio
productMatches.description:
Crisp and clean, this wine features honeydew, stone fruit, and citrus with a subtle, clean, lingering finish.
Try pairing with good old fish and chips, summer salads, and steamed clams by the dozen...or dozens.

instructions: Preheat oven to 350F. Wrap tortillas in foil; place in oven 10 minutes. Arrange tortillas on work surface. Press 2 tablespoons filling for corn or 3 tablespoons filling for flour tortillas into 3- to 4-inch strip on bottom third of each tortilla. Roll up; secure with toothpicks.Pour oil into large skillet to depth of 1 inch. Attach deep-fry thermometer; heat oil to 350F. Fry floutas 3 or 4 at a time until golden, turning occasionally, about 4 minutes. Using tons, hold flautas vertically over skillet to drain off oil; transfer to paper towels to drain. Remove toothpicks. Serve with shredded iceberg lettuce and sour cream.emailtwitterfacebookpinterestyummlymoreDont Miss a Recipe!Subscribe to receive new posts and monthly updates from L&OO:Send Me:New PostsNewsletter Previous PostLinguine with Shrimp, Asparagus, and BasilNext Post Balsamic Braised Mushrooms and CouscousLeave a CommentName (required)Mail (required - will not be published)Website URLComment (required)Cancel ReplyWelcome to Love & Olive Oil, the culinary adventures of Lindsay and Taylor. steps.step: Preheat oven to 350F. Wrap tortillas in foil; place in oven 10 minutes. Arrange tortillas on work surface. Press 2 tablespoons filling for corn or 3 tablespoons filling for flour tortillas into 3- to 4-inch strip on bottom third of each tortilla.
Roll up; secure with toothpicks.

Pour oil into large skillet to depth of 1 inch. Attach deep-fry thermometer; heat oil to 350F. Fry floutas 3 or 4 at a time until golden, turning occasionally, about 4 minutes. Using tons, hold flautas vertically over skillet to drain off oil; transfer to paper towels to drain.
Remove toothpicks.
Serve with shredded iceberg lettuce and sour cream.emailtwitterfacebookpinterestyummlymore
